contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox settlement |official_name = Itapira, São Paulo - Brazil |image_shield = Brasao Itapira SaoPaulo Brasil.svg |image_flag = Bandeira Itapira SaoPaulo Brasil.svg |pushpin_map = |pushpin_label_position = |pushpin_map_caption = |pushpin_mapsize = |pushpin_map1 = |pushpin_label_position1 = |pushpin_map_caption1 = |pushpin_mapsize1 = |coordinates_display = inline,title |coordinates_region = BR |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = {{BRA}} |subdivision_type1 = [[State of São Paulo|São Paulo]] |subdivision_name1 = |subdivision_type2 = |subdivision_name2 = |established_title = |established_date = 1820 |population_as_of = 2010 |population_total = 68,365 |population_density_km2 = 0.13 |latd = |latm = |longd = |longm = |latNS=S|longEW=O |elevation_m = 643 |postal_code_type = |postal_code = [ |area_code = +55 19 |website = }} {{Coord|22|26|10|S|46|49|18|W|scale:30000|display=title}} '''Itapira''' is a municipality in the state of [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]] in [[Brazil]]. Its population in 2010 was 68,365 and the area is 518.89 km². The elevation is 643 m. Founded around 1820, the name Itapira (meaning Stone Fish in the [[Tupi language]]) was officially adopted in 1890 .<ref>Itapira (in Portuguese Wikipedia) [[:pt:Itapira]]</ref> The current mayor is José Natalino Paganini, an ex-footballer. Itapira services an agricultural hinterland which grows oranges, sugar-cane, cattle and (now-declining) coffee,<ref>[http://www.itapira.sp.gov.br/institucional/revista/ Revista Informativa Sobre A Cidade de Itapira]</ref> but is also a manufacturing centre, specializing in wood and paper products, agricultural machinery, and ethanol production. The establishment in 1937 (by [[Spiritism|spiritist]] groups) of the pioneering Instituto Bairral<ref>[http://www.bairral.com.br/nossa_historia.html Instituto Bairral: Nossa História]</ref> psychiatric hospital in Itapira has fostered a well-developed health sector, both public and private. The town is home to a large number of professionals (such as the noted economist J.B. de Souza Ferreira Fo.), many of whom commute to neighbouring towns such as [[Campinas]]. The town's Historical Museum displays interesting relics of one of the last major battles of the [[Constitutionalist Revolution|Paulista War]], which was fought nearby. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{São Paulo state|Campinas}} [[Category:Populated places in São Paulo (state)]] {{SaoPauloState-geo-stub}}
